title: Teachings on Marriage and Discipleship
shortSummary: Matthew 19 records Jesus’ teachings on marriage, divorce, and the kingdom of heaven, emphasizing the sacredness of the marital union and the cost of true discipleship. The chapter also highlights Jesus’ compassion for children and challenges the rich young ruler to prioritize eternal life over earthly wealth.
timeline: c. AD 30 - Ministry of Jesus in Judea beyond Jordan

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Messiah and teacher who instructs on marriage, divorce, discipleship, and the kingdom of heaven.

keyCharacters.name: Pharisees
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who question Jesus about the lawfulness of divorce, attempting to test Him.

keyCharacters.name: Disciples
keyCharacters.description: Followers of Jesus who learn from His teachings and express amazement at His words.

keyCharacters.name: Rich Young Man
keyCharacters.description: A seeker who asks Jesus about eternal life but struggles to surrender his wealth.

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: A disciple who inquires about the reward for those who have forsaken all to follow Jesus.

definitions.definition: An archaic phrase meaning to divorce or send away a wife.
Men who are unable to marry or procreate, either by birth, by human action, or by personal choice for the kingdom of heaven.
A legal certificate or document given to a wife to formalize a divorce under Mosaic law.
The reign and rule of God, both present spiritually and future in fullness.

outline.heading: Jesus Teaches on Marriage and Divorce
outline.description: Jesus responds to the Pharisees’ question about divorce, affirming God’s original design for marriage as a lifelong union between one man and one woman, and explaining the allowance of divorce due to human hardness of heart.

outline.heading: Jesus Blesses the Children
outline.description: Jesus welcomes little children, rebuking His disciples for hindering them, and declares that the kingdom of heaven belongs to such as these, emphasizing childlike faith.

outline.heading: The Rich Young Man’s Question
outline.description: A young man asks Jesus about eternal life; Jesus instructs him to keep the commandments and then challenges him to sell his possessions and follow Him, revealing the cost of discipleship.

outline.heading: The Difficulty for the Rich to Enter the Kingdom
outline.description: Jesus teaches that riches can hinder entrance into the kingdom of heaven, using the metaphor of a camel passing through the eye of a needle, and assures that with God all things are possible.

outline.heading: Rewards for Those Who Follow Jesus
outline.description: Peter asks about the reward for forsaking all to follow Jesus; Jesus promises a place of honor in the coming kingdom and eternal life, concluding with the principle that the first shall be last and the last first.

application: Honor the sacredness of marriage by upholding God’s design for lifelong fidelity and resisting the temptation to divorce except in cases of marital unfaithfulness.
Embrace childlike faith and welcome others, especially children, into the fellowship of Christ without hindrance or prejudice.
Evaluate your attachments to material possessions and be willing to surrender them to follow Jesus wholeheartedly.
Trust in God’s power to accomplish what is impossible for man, especially in matters of salvation and spiritual growth.

keyVerses.text: Wherefore they are no more twain, but one flesh. What therefore God hath joined together, let not man put asunder.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the divine institution of marriage as an unbreakable union.

keyVerses.text: But Jesus said, Suffer little children, and forbid them not, to come unto me: for of such is the kingdom of heaven.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the importance of childlike faith and Jesus’ welcoming heart toward the vulnerable.

keyVerses.text: And again I say unto you, It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.
keyVerses.significance: Emphasizes the spiritual danger of wealth and the need for dependence on God for salvation.

keyVerses.text: And every one that hath forsaken houses, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, for my name's sake, shall receive an hundredfold, and shall inherit everlasting life.
keyVerses.significance: Promises abundant eternal rewards for those who sacrifice for Christ’s sake.
